title: JPMorgan/Tesla: maths dispute is rare public kerfuffle between bank and client
text:
Very few punch-ups would have JPMorgan Chase as the lightweight. But when the megabank sued Tesla for a modest $162m on Monday over a hedging transaction, it took on a legal battle with a company whose market capitalisation of $1tn is twice its own value.

Tesla's spectacular ascent is the source of the contretemps. In 2014, JPMorgan bought warrants on the stock to help the electric vehicle company manage potential dilution from a convertible bond.

Tesla's shares have risen more than 20 times since. The warrants are easily in the money.

The bank and carmaker disagree over the strike price on the warrants as a result of Elon Musk's ill-fated buyout plan in 2018. Tesla does not believe itself accountable for the resulting confusion. Perhaps bank boss Jamie Dimon is the guy to strike a rare blow.

Three maths wizards hover over the dispute: Myron Scholes, Fischer Black and Robert Merton. They developed the equation to value stock options. Share price volatility is a key input. The higher it is, the more likely a call option or warrant will rise above the strike price.

JPMorgan says its contract allowed the agreed-upon strike price of $561 per share to be adjusted for events including a possible sale of the company. Because Musk's tweet stated a $420 offer price, volatility crashed. JPMorgan calculated that the strike price needed to be reset to $425. When the buyout fell through and volatility rose again, the bank said the proper strike price was $485.

By this summer, Tesla shares traded for more than $3,000, on a pre-split basis. JPMorgan contends it hedged the warrants based on the revised strike price while keeping Tesla informed. The bank says its $162m reflects net losses on hedging resulting from a rebased exercise price Tesla allegedly refuses to acknowledge.         

Banks and corporate clients routinely brush disagreements under the rug out of mutual need. This clash of the titans signals a breakdown in relations that would be surprising, if unpredictable Tesla was not involved.
